prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For having a sleepover with my (21M) friend (22F) and not asking my girlfriend (20F)?
Title is pretty self explanatory but here goes.

One of my closest friends at uni, Annie (who is in a long term relationship) came over one night to have a couple of drinks before heading to a party. One of our friends bailed and we didn’t want to go to the party alone so we watched TV and smoked a couple of Js. The TV is in my room and we fell asleep together. 

My girlfriend of 2 years was at a concert with a girl friend at the time and since we had decided not to go to the party anymore went back to her place instead of coming over.

I told her the next morning that Annie fell asleep in my bed and thought nothing of it for the next few days.

The next time I saw her she sat me down and very seriously explained why she thought what had happened was super inappropriate, she also brought up a bunch of stuff that I hadn’t noticed. Like how she thought Annie would overstep boundaries by playing with my hair and holding my hand at a festival while my girlfriend was walking alone behind. This stuff did happen but I meant nothing by it and love my girlfriend to death. 

My girlfriend did say that I hadn’t done anything wrong because I had never initiated this, but I also hadn’t noticed that it had bothered her.

She said that the whole situation probably wouldn’t have bothered her if it weren’t for one conversation.

We have often talked about having threesomes and which of our friends we would sleep with. Obviously not seriously but we just find it interesting to explore each other’s tastes-and I said Annie. 

After her pointing this out I feel like I’m hyper aware of how I am acting around Annie and I fear it will change our friendship.

AITA for feeling that my GF blowed this out of proportion and letting this affect my friendship with Annie? 

TL;DR : My girlfriend got angry with me because my friend slept over in my bed and she thinks this friend crosses the line too much.


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for having a sleepover with a female friend without informing their girlfriend. 

First, the setup: The author (21M) had a friend, Annie (22F), over to watch TV after a friend bailed on a party. They ended up falling asleep in his room. The girlfriend (20F) was at a concert with a friend and later found out. The girlfriend felt it was inappropriate, especially because the couple had joked about threesomes and the author mentioned Annie. 

The key points here are consent and communication. The author didn't ask his girlfriend about the sleepover, which is a point of contention. Even if it was accidental or innocent, not discussing it beforehand could be seen as a breach of trust. The girlfriend's reaction stems from feeling that boundaries were crossed, particularly because of past conversations about threesomes involving Annie. 

The author claims he didn't initiate any of the interactions and thought nothing of it. However, the girlfriend felt neglected and that the situation was a trigger for her insecurities. The fact that they had previously discussed threesomes (even jokingly) might have made her more sensitive to Annie's presence. 

In relationships, communication is crucial. Even if the actions themselves were innocent, the lack of communication can lead to misunderstandings. The author didn't consider how the girlfriend might feel about Annie being in his room or the previous jokes about threesomes. 

Additionally, the author now feels anxious about his friendship with Annie, which shows that his actions affected more than just the current situation. The girlfriend's perspective is valid because her feelings matter in the relationship. 

So, while the author didn't intentionally do anything wrong, the lack of communication and consideration for his girlfriend's feelings could be seen as a mistake. Therefore, he might be at least partially at fault.
